key_points: Former Officer Derek Chauvin declined to testify in George Floyd's death trial, invoking his Fifth Amendment right.
Closing arguments in the trial are set to begin Monday, with jury deliberation to follow.
The trial's outcome is highly anticipated, prompting Minneapolis public schools to shift to distance learning in anticipation of a verdict.
The defense rested its case after two days of testimony, in contrast to the prosecution's two weeks.
Chauvin is charged with murder and manslaughter in the death of George Floyd, facing up to 40 years in prison for the most serious charge, second-degree murder.
Worldwide protests were triggered by bystander video showing Chauvin pressing his knee against Floyd's neck.
Prosecutors argue Floyd died due to Chauvin's knee pressed against his neck or close to it for 9 1/2 minutes.
Defense testimony aimed to present Chauvin's actions as reasonable and suggested Floyd's death was due to health issues and drug use.
The only time Chauvin has been heard defending himself was through body-camera footage shown to the jury.
The trial is happening amid ongoing protests over another police shooting in the Minneapolis suburb of Brooklyn Center.
